docs.abstract: Humanity faces a complex knot of seemingly distinct but entangled crises that are causing damage greater than the sum of their individual harms.
docs.snippet: Humanity faces a complex knot of seemingly distinct but entangled crises that are causing damage greater than the sum of their individual harms.
docs.lead_paragraph: It seems as if the world is encountering a “perfect storm” of simultaneous crises: The coronavirus pandemic is approaching the end of its third year; the war in Ukraine is threatening to go nuclear; extreme climate events are afflicting North America, Europe, Asia and Africa; and inflation is reaching rates unseen in decades and authoritarianism is on the march around the world. But the storm metaphor implies that this simultaneity is an unfortunate and temporary coincidence — that it’s humanity’s bad luck that everything seems to be going haywire all at once.

headline.main: What Happens When a Cascade of Crises Collide?

byline.original: By Thomas Homer-Dixon and Johan Rockström

docs.abstract: Citing flaws in the way the ratings are determined, the schools said they will stop participating, breaking away from the rankings industry.
docs.snippet: Citing flaws in the way the ratings are determined, the schools said they will stop participating, breaking away from the rankings industry.
docs.lead_paragraph: In perhaps the biggest challenge yet to the school rankings industry, both Yale and Harvard announced Wednesday that they were withdrawing from the influential U.S. News & World Report rankings of the nation’s best law schools.

headline.main: Yale and Harvard Law Schools Withdraw From the U.S. News Rankings
headline.print_headline: Both Harvard and Yale Remove Schools of Law From Ranking System

docs.abstract: What’s good for credit-card companies isn’t always good for customers.
docs.snippet: What’s good for credit-card companies isn’t always good for customers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Six dollars and 50 cents is a lot to pay for a scoop of ice cream, no matter how artisanal. But that’s the cost at Van Leeuwen’s 20 ice cream shops in New York City. It’s especially egregious when you consider that a full pint of Van Leeuwen, which contains two and a half servings of ice cream, depending on your self-discipline, costs only a few dollars more.

docs.abstract: The winners of races at every level of government will play crucial roles in overseeing and certifying the 2024 presidential election.
docs.snippet: The winners of races at every level of government will play crucial roles in overseeing and certifying the 2024 presidential election.
docs.lead_paragraph: Midterm elections in the United States are often presented as a referendum on the party in power, and that message appears to be resonating this fall. But voters need to consider the intentions of the party that hopes to regain power, too, and what each vote they cast will mean for the future of this country.

headline.main: What’s at Stake in These Elections
headline.print_headline: What’s at Stake in These Elections

docs.abstract: Who loses if we raise the age of Social Security eligibility?
docs.snippet: Who loses if we raise the age of Social Security eligibility?
docs.lead_paragraph: My Thursday column is about the assault on Medicare and Social Security that is almost certain to follow if Republicans prevail on Tuesday. If the G.O.P. wins control of Congress, we can expect it to hold the economy hostage, most obviously by weaponizing the debt ceiling, in an attempt to force big cuts in Medicare and Social Security.

headline.main: Wonking Out: Stealing Away the Golden Years of the Working Class

docs.abstract: Never mind the “populism”; it’s still a rich man’s party.
docs.snippet: Never mind the “populism”; it’s still a rich man’s party.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Times recently reported that Republicans, anticipating possible victory in the midterms, are embracing plans to cut Social Security and Medicare benefits — even though such cuts would be incredibly unpopular and would make nonsense of the G.O.P.’s attempts to portray itself as the party of the working class.

headline.main: The G.O.P. Plot Against Medicare and Social Security

docs.abstract: The share of first-time buyers fell to 26 percent, plummeting to the lowest level in four decades, when a real estate trade association began tracking such data.
docs.snippet: The share of first-time buyers fell to 26 percent, plummeting to the lowest level in four decades, when a real estate trade association began tracking such data.
docs.lead_paragraph: American home buyers are older, whiter and wealthier than at any time in recent memory, with first-time buyers accounting for the smallest share of the market in 41 years, the National Association of Realtors found in its annual profile of home buyers and sellers.

headline.main: Older, White and Wealthy Home Buyers Are Pushing Others Out of the Market
headline.print_headline: First-Time Buyers Losing Out to the Older, Whiter and Wealthier

docs.abstract: Getting shots into arms isn’t rocket science, or at least it shouldn’t be.
docs.snippet: Getting shots into arms isn’t rocket science, or at least it shouldn’t be.
docs.lead_paragraph: El Buen Samaritano, an Episcopal outreach ministry in Texas, serves the east side of Austin, the poorer of the two parts of the city, split by I-35. There are fewer services there, including many neighborhoods that don’t have a health center. The population is mainly people of color, many whose first language is Spanish. It’s the kind of population that has low Covid vaccination rates.

headline.main: The New Covid Boosters Are Incredible, and Everyone Should Get One
headline.print_headline: Let’s Get the New Booster to Everyone

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

docs.abstract: White working-class support for right-wing populism is hardening.
docs.snippet: White working-class support for right-wing populism is hardening.
docs.lead_paragraph: Even as the economic pressures that drove millions of white working-class voters to the right are moderating, the hostility this key segment of the electorate feels toward the Democratic Party has deepened and is less and less amenable to change.

headline.main: ‘Elites Are Making Choices That Are Not Good News’

docs.abstract: New York City joins a handful of states in requiring employers to disclose salary ranges for openings. The goal is to narrow disparities.
docs.snippet: New York City joins a handful of states in requiring employers to disclose salary ranges for openings. The goal is to narrow disparities.
docs.lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offer a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline.main: New Laws Force Honesty About Pay. Companies Are Catching Up.
headline.print_headline: New Laws Force Companies To Talk Frankly About Salaries

byline.original: By Emma Goldberg and Sarah Kessler
